results.description: Set in a rainforest environment, Singapore Zoo's world-famous "Open Concept” offers the opportunity to experience and be inspired by the wonders of nature. Home to more than 2,400 specimens of over 300 species, 34 per cent of which are threatened, the Zoo has attained a strong reputation internationally for its conservation initiatives and breeding programmes.
results.name: Singapore Zoo

reviews.text: it's good but the exhibition needs to be updated. the version I remember have shooting gallery and army weapon. how we the discovery center in 2019 is about nation building and some games seem to have here since 2007 and require a upgrade. I wish it can showcase new technology like the discovery center we remember when we are children and not a history museum looking back at our past.

Went here during my primary school, secondary school and NS (oh god...) days. There's something for everyone, from science to history, at really affordable rates. I guess it's one of those places that parents would want to bring their children.

Great experience for us, especially for the kids! The interactive facilities are especially appealing for a quiet weekend. We liked the movie theater and 3D shows. All in all, great place to go if you have spare time.

Love the low price of theatre movie ticket. There are also 3D glasses for 3D movies! Check out the website for show times. Love the unblocked view from the lecture- theatre-like seats! The food snacks and drinks are also at affordable price just located outside the theatre.

Have a chance to learn how Singapore consciously learn from the past to build a better future for the nation. The entrance is free for Singaporeans and there are also free guided tours that we can go on so that we can get access to otherwise restricted areas and explore different exhibits that they have in the area. It's pretty much a Social Studies lesson outside the classroom.

results.body: Visitors to the Singapore Discovery Centre will be able to immerse themselves in Singapore’s past, present and future through interactive and hands-on multi-sensory exhibits. They can, for example, attempt to save the country from a “bomb blast” or master the dances of various ethnic groups. Guided tours of the permanent exhibits gallery are scheduled on a first-come, first-served basis.
results.description: Learn more about the Singapore story through interactive and hands-on multi-sensory exhibits.
results.name: Singapore Discovery Centre

reviews.text: Beautiful arrangements and architecture, awesome building. We can get good clear picture about Singapore history and culture. I was enjoyed and learn lot about thire history.. Each and everyone should visit this place in your life time. It's Quite silent, nice and calm place. Good maintenance. Keep it up. Good luck.
Neat museum, and it used to be a school building. The best feat of it is that it’s free. Gallery is okay, nothing special. If you’re a tourist you can easily skip this one.

If you are living in Singapore then you should definitely visit this National Museum one day because this shows you the history of Singapore by various exhibitions, historic objects and many audio clippings. 
The Museum shows you the beginning of this land by portraits and clips too
If you are an art lover you should not miss this place in Level 1 (history) cause you will love it.
In Level 2 its a forest journey and you will enjoy if you're with your family or friends
Your kids will love the 3D experience in Level2.
A Basement Level is also opened now which is about Polaroid.  If you are a science lover you will love it.
Altogether it was a good experience.

An interesting Art Museum showing rare masterpieces of Claude Monet and other Impressionists. I expected less from this museum, but was impressed to see loaned masterpieces from European galleries, like d'Orsay. At time of our visit (March 2018) there was a special exhibition, showing masterpieces from Monet, Renoir, Juan Luna and others. The building itself is a spectacular, Neoclassical in style, but too large for the pieces of art i offers. An hour is enough to take at look at the most prominent pictures.
Nice art museum that is located in the former boy Catholic school historic building, displays drawing, painting, installation, sculptures, etc.

results.body: The Singapore Art Museum (SAM) has a great collection of contemporary art from the region. It has showcased a variety of paintings, sculptures & art installations by various artists. Its permanent gallery, Once Upon This Island, comprises works by 12 Singapore-based artists that explore what it means to live in this contemporary city-state. Travellers can also visit SAM at 8Q, a wing of the museum located across the road, to see the Moving Image Gallery, where film screenings are held. There are cafés and restaurants for visitors to have a meal after art appreciation.

pricing.others: Adult: S$10, Senior Citizen: S$5; Free admission for Children

results.nearestMrtStation: Bras Basah Station / Dhoby Ghaut Station
results.description: A former boy’s mission school, the museum is home to a collection of contemporary art from the region, including works by 12 Singapore-based artists.
results.name: Singapore Art Museum

reviews.text: One of the free attractions in Singapore, and a nice place to bring kids and pets. For a great day out choose a cooler day, bring a basket or some snacks and a blanket and just relax in the lush gardens. There's quite a bit of history in the gardens so do pay some attention to that, there are some interesting facts. While there, visit the National Orchid Garden. Makes a good half day visit. Best times are morning and late afternoons when the day time temperatures dip slightly.

Well worth the time. It’s busy, it’s free - except for the Orchid Garden (but worth the entry fee). Lovely walks through different climatic forests and gardens. Colourful and contemplative. Singapore has done well again! And apparently you can take your dogs, which were more attractive to the myriad of kids than the flora.

Wonderful gardens, so lively, well and maintained, leafy. Where else, can we see a park that is a UNESCO heritage park! At this place, one feels real harmony with nature. It has a few small lakes which are fairly tranquil. 
It's an ideal place to have a weekend picnic and for enjoying some family time. On a bright, breezy afternoon there is no better place than the Botanic Gardens.

One of my favorite parts of visiting Singapore. If you get to where the restaurant and pavilion area is, the breeze is amazing. For a moment, you might even not sweat and forget that you're in a humid place. 

Great fauna and flora. Saw a monitor lizard which was a bonus. Bring a snack and beverage to find hang out.

Great food great service and good ambience. We were there for birthday celebration and it was the right choice. As we are small eater we ordered the 5 course dinner. But Look at the pics the Portion is huge. And at the end of dinner we were given a Corner house  box of cookies. Will be back!

results.body: Set in lush greenery, the 158-year-old Singapore Botanic Gardens is the country’s first UNESCO World Heritage Site and the only tropical botanic garden on the list. Its impressive, ornate main gate is a not-to-be-missed photo opportunity. It boasts four pillars and supporting swinging gates framing a cast-aluminium lattice of Bauhinia kockiana, the climber planted at the fencing just beside it. Inside, the gardens is a showcase of spectacular tropical flora, with various species of plants and flowers that makes beautiful photo backdrop.
results.admissionInfo: Free
results.description: The country’s first UNESCO World Heritage Site is a showcase of spectacular tropical flora. There are also many idyllic photo spots throughout the Gardens such as Swan Lake and The Bandstand gazebo.
results.name: Singapore Botanic Gardens

reviews.text: I feel like this is an underrated place in Singapore! Although small, this museum is really interesting and offers great insight into the world of letters and postcards! If you're a postcard lover, this is the place to be. Great selection of postcards and stamps as well. This is also a nice place to visit with children since some of the displays in the museum can be touched/interacted with. Be prepared to spend around an hour and a half in this place. :)

Visited the museum for the little prince exhibition. Singapore citizens and PR get in for free and everyone else pays only $8. You can easily spend an hour here and perhaps 2 hours if you read every single description. I enjoyed the unexpectedly high quality exhibitions and it’s probably one of the most overlooked museums in Singapore!

This museum is small but its packed with information and constantly strives to keep young people interested in stamps ! 

Will miss the museum for awhile  when its closed for upgrading from 18 March 2019 until end of year 2020.

Its current exihibits on Little Prince will definitely encourage young people to find out about these books.
Polite kind staff. Interesting rare stamps: I saw stamps limited with the Little prince. The ability to send mail anywhere! Thank kond staff for your help!

What a surprising find. While Singapore is home to some phenomenal museums showcasing international (as well as local) art and cultural, the philatelic museum goes above and beyond a "postal museum" to tell the story of how the post has helped foster community through communication across culture. The exhibits are intricately detailed and fascinating!

results.body: More than just payment for postage, stamps shed light on the culture, history and milestones of a country. At the Singapore Philatelic Museum, which is housed in a century-old colonial building, visitors will find an enchanting collection of more than 12,000 stamps and objects related to the country’s postal system. With beginnings dating back to the 1830s, the collection here was acquired in Singapore and overseas. Look out for the world’s first stamp and the museum’s crown jewel - the only known complete set of 1854 Indian stamps, which were used in the Straits Settlements.

pricing.others: Adult: S$8, Child: S$6, Senior Citizen: S$6

results.description: Here visitors can find Singapore’s only operating colonial postbox outside the museum as well as 12,000 stamps and objects related to the country’s postal system.
results.name: Singapore Philatelic Museum

reviews.text: A must see, particularly for visitors to Singapore who want to understand how the country works and overcomes the challenges presented by small size and large population. The new gallery wings set to open in a few months are fantastically detailed and interactive, meaning a fun experience for both adults and children alike. The huge model of the Singapore City Centre is a highlight and not often crowded. Well worth a visit.

It is very educational and fun for the kids. It gives a very good perspective how Singapore develop along the years from a kampong to current metropolitan.They also have guided tours in certain days. 
It is good to bring the kids and spend half a day here. In one of the section, they can create their own city using the simulation. Take note they only open on weekdays and Saturday.
Dream up a revitalized cityscape here.. Definitely worth a visit! plus look at those classy-yet-cute cushions

I love scale models so this review may be biased because I saw the largest and most detailed scale model of anything in this place. If you are a fan or urban planning you'd love this place. The downside was that there were spaces that can't be access because it is still in renovation.

The Singapore City Gallery is a really nice place. In the main floor there are the master plans of the city and a place where you can just sit and take a break. 
In the first floor there is a bis 3D model of the whole city, it is really amazing.
If you go to the 3rd floor you can take a great picture of it.
There is also a (public) toilet

results.body: The Singapore City Gallery offers insights into the country’s physical transformation from fishing village to first-world metropolis. Learn about Singapore’s urban planning efforts through audio-visual and interactive exhibits spanning over three storeys. A large model of the city centre, enhanced by light and sounds, gives visitors a comprehensive overview of modern Singapore, including its landmarks and skyscrapers. The gallery’s other highlight is “A Day in Singapore” - a 270° multimedia panoramic display - that pieces together scenes of daily life in Singapore. Admission is free.
results.description: Learn about the urban planning efforts that tranformed the country from a fishing village into a first-world metropolis.
results.name: Singapore City Gallery

reviews.text:
Here is your chance to really fly. Experience true free-fall conditions, just like a real skydive. Each flyer will enjoy two skydives in the wind tunnel. The time it takes for each skydive is like falling through the air from 12,000 to 3,000 feet! And at one-fifth the cost of a tandem jump, iFly Singapore is unbeatable value.

We are beside the Beach Station, down at Siloso Beachfront in Sentosa, Singapore. The Beach Station is a focal point for all transports including Sentosa buses, trams, trains and taxis. Should you wish to drive, there are over 600 parking lots located at the basement of the station.

For your convenience and enjoyment, we are pleased to offer a variety of F&B tenants within iFly Singapore itself.

One of the best experience for those who want to do the simulation of sky diving.
Actual sky diving is definitely not that comfortable as this one. This is safe, fun, short duration and expensive.
Expensive because of short duration 😜. 
The trainer was good and briefed everyone well before the session.
The flying experience is really good. One should have no back/shoulder injuries. If you do then it's dangerous for you.
Do a little stretching before the flying session. This helps!

Overall great experience so definitely 5 Starts.
Experience flight for a minute. It is great for first timers and the guides are experts. They make it look so easy. They give you a video of the action for 110 sgd.

Enough for kids and mindless amusement: a bit unprofessional if you really want to learn and do well.

The training session was too superficial and rushed, so had a lot of questions once in the tunnel. No break to ask once inside.

Needless to say, no stretching or muscle activation to prevent injuries, only a waiver about existing back problems. I'm an active person with no preexisting issues and I had a pinch on my back the night after.

Once in the tunnel, not sure how they calculated the time but I left without really knowing what to improve. Instead: the instructor performed a fancy demonstration to upsell additional time, sessions and pics, without letting me out.

After most people bought and used additional time, we still finished early... It was amusing but I was expecting better tips.

I was here on the 1st of December, 2018.  It was a first visit. What struck me as awkward was the simulated training session. Also, they do not mention the importance of having to completely cover your hair. Not kidding, but I spent 2 whole days trying to entangle my hair and almost went crazy! Had to pull them apart strand by strand and now my hair is in shackles ! 

Make sure you ask a lot of questions before doing the actual sky-dive. 

The experience was pretty good. And is a superb simulation of the wind pressure up there. Other than that, it's not worth so much of your money... (And a lot of hair!!)

results.body: To live out the dream of soaring like a superhero, drop by iFly Singapore, Southeast Asia’s largest wind tunnel for indoor skydiving. The 18-foot-tall acrylic ‘glass walls’—allow visitors to enjoy panoramic views of the South China Sea and Siloso Beach. State-of-the-art technology will lend visitors wings in an experience that gives visitors a taste of skydiving and simulates free falls from heights of 12,000- to 3,000-feet. First timers needn’t fret, as trained professionals will be on hand to guide them.

pricing.others: 1 Skydive S$89; 2 Skydives S$119 (walk-in); 2 Skydives S$109 (2 day in advance online rate); 2 Skydives S$89 (2 day in advance online off-peak rate)

results.description: Enjoy skydives in wind tunnels for an unforgettable experience.
results.name: iFly Singapore

reviews.text: This is a great place to take kids. They have so many activities and exhibits that are fascinating. We have had a great time there. I wish they had more to offer little kids, and I felt there were too many "extra" charges (just include everything in the one package). But overall it is a lot of fun, and I'd recommend it for families.

A place of science. I visited this place in the winter of 2019. It was a lively place with lots of models, real-time experimental labs, live shows. They have entrance fee. Highly recommended for children. 4-5 hours enough!

Very old fashioned displays, even the newer items. In one room a only interaction was going through a PowerPoint presentation using a large red button
My kids did enjoy though
Was raining so we could not use the outdoor water park, maybe with it we could have given a 4

Great place for the kids to learn in a fun and exciting way . Both my 11 and 6 year old equally enjoyed the visit.  Entry is free although in would have been happy to pay as there is so much on offer .

Awesome experience. Not only for children, but for adults too. Omni-theater is one of a kind and amazing. Fire tornado show is not to be missed. And the gift shop has so many nice items all based on scientific concepts. One day is not enough to cover all the exhibits and shows. Totally worth every penny.

results.body:
A leading regional Science Centre in Asia, Science Centre Singapore aims to promote interest, learning and creativity in science and technology through imaginative and immersive experiences.

Along with its group of attractions –KidsSTOP™, Omni-Theatre, and Snow City – this family-friendly Centre brings out the wonders of science, technology, engineering and mathematics through its unique blend of exhibitions, educational programmes and events.

The Centre also plays a pivotal role in transforming the way students and the public interact with and learn about these topics.

Since 1977, Science Centre Singapore has welcomed over 30 million visitors and inspired them with more than 1,000 exhibits spread across 14 exhibition galleries and outdoor exhibition spaces.
results.amenities: ATMs Check,Carpark,Free Wi-Fi,Gift Shop,Serves Halal Food,Wheelchair Accessible
results.admissionInfo:
Adult: $12
Children: $8
results.description: One of the leading science centres in the region
results.name: Science Centre Singapore

reviews.text: Quite an interesting place to be. You can easily spend about 2-3 hours here going from one room to the other taking pictures. Definitely worth a place where toi should go with a company.  Recommended to wear comfy footwear as you need to walk here. Vibrant and colourful! Lifts up your mood with its witty ideas

Very good experience. Worth the money paid. 
 Good quality camera is must to get the photos more realistic. Won't recommend going alone, go with team or at least with one extra person with you.

Place is ideal for kids and adults who are crazy about getting insta friendly pics and only for pics .. Use of a AR app is must to get those kind of pics we see which people share . Make it a point to  keep your phone's fully charged as the AR app drains your battery in minutes, better keep a battery pack to charge in need. If you need to fill in for some extra time then pack this attraction in your schedule , else you got better attractions and experiences worth your time .

A nice treat to all the illusion lovers.. amazing work of trick for the eye. I have seen elders enjoying more than the kids.. they also have a inhouse app that makes the photo very dramatic and lively. It would take 1 to 1.5 hr for the entire session, but worth one visit. This is located at the main entrance of Sentosa, so don't miss it.

Liked the museum especially with the augmented reality view. Interesting place. A lot to do and experience. A word of advice, take multiple power banks to keep mobile charged.

We realized, after more than 200 photos that the phone batteries were going dead and then had to leave some photo scenes

And you will end up taking the same amount ot photos. Extremely engaging esp through the Augmented reality app.

Must see and highly recommended

results.body: Get ready to let your imagination run wild in Trick Eye Museum Singapore, an internationally renowned 3D art museum from Korea. With its huge array of art exhibits hand-painted by dedicated Korean artists, each exhibit comes alive with the use of a special art technique that makes 2D art pop up into 3D. Feel, touch and interact with the exhibits in 6 different zones, and enjoy a day filled with fun, laughter, adventure and excitement. With Trick Eye Museum’s very own Augmented Reality mobile app, you will discover a hidden world of Augmented Reality seen only through the app. Download the “Trickeye” app and watch as your photos and videos come alive with hidden animals, magic, fireworks and other special effects!
results.admissionInfo:
Adults (13-59 yrs) $25, Child (4-12 yrs) $20, Senior (60 yrs above) $20.

Open daily from 10am to 9pm (last admission 8pm)
results.description: Singapore's First 3D + AR Museum
results.name: Trick Eye Museum Singapore

reviews.text: A nice place to spend approximately half a day. Very beautiful exhibits and the building is huge. It's easy to miss out on some beautiful art if you can't figure out the navigation inside. I went on a Saturday when the entry happened to be free and it wasn't very crowded. You can enjoy the exhibits and pop into one of their many restaurants. I was surprised to find good food for a pretty decent amount in one of the cafes.

Husband works next to this place at the Supreme Courts so this place is my coffee fix or waiting area till he is off work. Sit around, or walk the galleries. Very very relaxing and good fun. It used to be the old Supreme Courts and wow, they have really preserved this place really well. Well done.

Much more than a Museum this place is an experience. Superb exhibits. Architecturally stunning. A masterpiece of modern engendering and design. You will need a day at least and you still won't see everything. Fantastic Place! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐👍
Beautiful place and art. I love having my family come along for a walk whenever there are some exhibition coming to town. Great! Walk around and do sit down for coffee. Most enjoyable.

A sanctuary for art-lovers. Very impressive. The building is beautiful as well as huge—it may take a day or so to explore it completely. I recently visited the minimalism exhibition, which certainly did not disappoint. If you happen to be in Singapore, this place is a must-visit!

results.body:
Situated in the heart of the Singapore Civic District, National Gallery Singapore oversees the largest public collection of modern art in Southeast Asia. Housed in two beautifully restored national monuments - City Hall and former Supreme Court - are impeccably curated exhibitions that reveal the cultural legacy and art histories of Southeast Asia. 

Come visit the Gallery today and discover the rich art and cultural heritage of Singapore and Southeast Asia through stunning modern art masterpieces.
results.admissionInfo:
General Admission: $20,
General Admission (Singaporean & PR): Free, 
Special Exhibitions: $25, 
All Access Pass: $30
results.description: Situated in the heart of the Singapore Civic District, National Gallery Singapore oversees the largest public collection of modern art in Southeast Asia.
results.name: National Gallery Singapore

reviews.text: This one is Must Visit. They have a very unique way of telling you the story of Singapore. Actors are good. Its like a live drama where you are involved in it.

Very informative live show from hosters. Speech given by them was really appreciatable. Speech and voice modulation from them will attract children's as well. I see the hostress are very young but their way of presenting the story will make you to listen the Singapore story.

Worst experience ever!!

I have never written any bad reviews online for anything but this experience is very disappointing! 

We were in group of four , 1 adult, one toddler, 1 kid and 1 elderly. 

We bought our tickets on Sentosa website. However we were treated very rudely at the entrance ( like that we didn’t want to pay ?!) and we were shouted at by a staff in front of at least 30 people. 

The entrance counter was badly managed and it was a mess . They took some tickets from us and let us in . Then later they realised they needed another set of tickets from us. 

A member of staff , a lady in white shirt was very rude and sarcastic to us . She and a few member of staffs are unable to empathise customers (my toddler was crying as they wanted me leave the queue and find the right set of tickets , isn’t that their responsibility to get it right the first time before I entered?!)

This experience leave us a very bad impression of Sentosa and even Singapore. 

The show itself was forced and acting was bad. Thirty minutes is a big waste of time. 

Use your time and money to visit other attraction !

Will not visit again ! Bad experience

We bought our tickets via Sentosa website. The redemption of tickets are troublesome , needed to queue up in 3 different places in order to finally get into the museum . 

We have a toddler with stroller. Before the redemption of tickets , there were nobody (at 3 different queues , they all saw us with stroller ) told us that stroller is not allowed . Only after we redempted our tickets then they said no stroller is allowed , which is very inconvenient for us as my toddler won’t able to walk long way. They should have put a notice in front or at least let us know before we redempt our tickets . 

The staff at the entrance is not efficient too. They let our family in , after we walked quite a long way (without stroller holding my toddler) they suddenly told me they forgot to take my recipt earlier! (I was so confused that aren’t they supposed to take it while I was walking in) I had to walk all the way back to outside the building to the stroller to get the receipt that they needed to keep for record. 

There was a lady (I believe she is the manger of the front staffs) was very rude to us too. It is definitely not what I expected in Sentosa which is a tourist place that staffs there should be polite and welcoming. Big disappointment! 

The acting of staff inside the museum is over-acting and the 30 mins acting was quite boring. I would prefer either they just tell us the history or I can read it on the wall myself. Basically you are forced to sit through the 30 mins bad acting . There is a sign said once you are in, you cannot exit half way. I wanted to leave as soon as I walked in. 

Will not recommend this place as it just not worth wasting time.
Perfect place to know the history of Singapore in brief.special mention to Mr Lee for giving detailed explanation of Singapore history.

results.body: Images of Singapore LIVE employs actors and special effects to construct a narrative of Singapore’s history from 1819 to the present day. During the 45-minute character-guided tour, visitors can interact with the guide and gain insights into Singapore’s history through 15 interactive areas. The tour ends with the Spirit of Singapore Boat Ride, during which iconic landmarks and the founder of modern Singapore, Sir Stamford Raffles, make an appearance.

pricing.others: Adult: (13-59 years old) S$39, Child: (3-12 years old) S$29

results.description: Watch actors and special effects construct a narrative of Singapore’s history from 1819 to the present day.
results.name: Images of Singapore LIVE

reviews.text: A nice place to spend approximately half a day. Very beautiful exhibits and the building is huge. It's easy to miss out on some beautiful art if you can't figure out the navigation inside. I went on a Saturday when the entry happened to be free and it wasn't very crowded. You can enjoy the exhibits and pop into one of their many restaurants. I was surprised to find good food for a pretty decent amount in one of the cafes.

Husband works next to this place at the Supreme Courts so this place is my coffee fix or waiting area till he is off work. Sit around, or walk the galleries. Very very relaxing and good fun. It used to be the old Supreme Courts and wow, they have really preserved this place really well. Well done.

Much more than a Museum this place is an experience. Superb exhibits. Architecturally stunning. A masterpiece of modern engendering and design. You will need a day at least and you still won't see everything. Fantastic Place! ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐👍
Beautiful place and art. I love having my family come along for a walk whenever there are some exhibition coming to town. Great! Walk around and do sit down for coffee. Most enjoyable.

A sanctuary for art-lovers. Very impressive. The building is beautiful as well as huge—it may take a day or so to explore it completely. I recently visited the minimalism exhibition, which certainly did not disappoint. If you happen to be in Singapore, this place is a must-visit!

results.body: National Gallery Singapore, in the heart of the Civic District is a state-of-the-art facility with an impressive collection of local & Southeast Asian artists. Two national monuments - the City Hall and former Supreme Court - were remodelled to create this stunning gallery. It is the biggest visual arts venue in Singapore housing the world's largest public collection of modern Southeast Asian art from the 19th century to the present. Its esteemed Southeast Asian catalogue carries names such as Indonesian Romantic painter Raden Saleh and Fernando Amorsolo from the Philippines.

pricing.others: Adult: S$20, Child: S$15, Senior Citizen: S$15

results.description: Two national monuments - the City Hall and former Supreme Court - were remodelled to create this splendid gallery, which offers an impressive collection of local and Southeast Asian artworks.
results.name: National Gallery Singapore

reviews.text: Great experience. A lot to discover about Singapore and where they're coming from. I loved the journey of transformation they've gone on. Gives me hope that my own Ghana will do well. Lunch here was great as well. Great all round experience.

The place to learn about Singapore’s history, this place takes you through what happened in Singapore in the last few hundred years to shape what it is today. Very educational and suitable for families to have a day visit. There are some interactive exhibits to keep kids entertained. 

The place is well maintained and recently refurbished. Service staff were fantastic. Cafe on site.

The place was neat and tidy as other museums should be. Those pieces of articles made me understood what life it's like during the Japanese occupation. There is a cafe below which you can have a hearty meal there.

I went to Flutes last night for dinner with my wife and daughter. Flutes is quite good, modern food done well. The service was good also. The wine list is nice and actually moderately priced. If you are looking for a slightly high end modern European meal I highly recommend.
This is a great museum. There is so much to see and do, you spend a whole day here. The cafe is great and very good value for money too. Lots of helpful guides around to help if you need.

results.body: The National Museum of Singapore is Singapore's oldest museum. Decades later, the redevelopment of this neoclassical structure incorporated a modern glass and metal extension, which more than doubled its area. Visitors can visit exhibitions that detail national History & Culture. A good starting point is the Singapore History Gallery, which maps the country’s growth. We Built A Nation, a permanent exhibition, contains several never-before-seen artefacts that chronicle Singapore’s first 10 years after its independence. The museum hosts performances, film screenings and events.

pricing.others: Adult: S$15, Senior Citizen: S$10; Free admission for Children

results.nearestMrtStation: Bras Basah Station / Dhoby Ghaut Station
results.description: This neoclassical structure is the oldest museum in the country, and it maps the growth of the nation from 700 years ago to the modern city-state it is today.
results.name: National Museum of Singapore

reviews.text: Super! Have a walk around here. There’s plenty of food, drinks, cafe and a very good crowd. Love it.
Nice place to chill along Singapore landmark. Many nice restaurants and good scenery. It's a good place to watch laser show of Marina Bay Sands at night.

Great restaurant options with a view of the marina bay sands, have been to the Pelican & Overeasy Restaurant/ Bars here.  All the places have a great outdoor and a cool indoor seating, so choose depending on the time of day and the time of year.

Cozy shopping mall with a sea view and a stone's throw away from Merlion Park and the Jubilee Bridge - great places for tourists to take photographs of Marina Bay Sands and the sea. The shopping mall also has cafes like Starbucks and restaurants such as Little Sheep Hot Pot
Very very good place for a dinner and walk around the Bay Area after.

results.body: On the lobby level of the Fullerton Hotel is the Fullerton Heritage Gallery, which displays decade-old photographs, maps, stamps and philatelic materials that showcase the precinct’s rich history. The precinct is walking distance to Merlion Park and is also a popular spot to watch the Marina Bay fireworks display on occasions like National Day and New Year’s Eve. On the guided Fullerton Monument Tour, visitors will discover the rich history of the Fullerton Building, where Singapore’s General Post Office was once located.
results.admissionInfo: Free
results.description: The Fullerton Heritage District showcases the precinct’s rich history and is also a popular spot to watch the Marina Bay fireworks display on occasions like National Day and New Year’s Eve.
results.name: The Fullerton Heritage Singapore

reviews.text: Strategic location.  Nice building deco, reminds me of Malacca and Penang.
Pusat informasi mengenai Singapura.jadi satu dengan hotel kapsul Cube.tapi sering ridak ada petugasnya

results.body: Before Tiong Bahru, there was Haji Lane ? Singapore's original hipster neighbourhood that's peppered with charming boutiques, watering holes, cafés, and restaurants.
results.description: A leisurely 10-minute walk away from Bugis MRT is an ethnic enclave turned shopping haven. Lined with an eclectic mix of generations-old heritage stores, independent boutiques and crafts shops, Kampong Glam?s shophouses are a welcome change from air-conditioned shopping centres. Much of its charm as the former home of the local Sultan (King) has been retained, yet new tenants inject fresh allure into one of Singapore?s most iconic heritage neighbourhoods. Wander through back alleys and along five-foot ways offering trinkets that you won?t usually find in any malls. Start from the shops around the biggest landmark, Sultan Mosque, and work your way into the narrow alleyways that are full of curious finds.
results.name: Kampong Glam Singapore Visitor Centre

results.body:
The dragon kiln, a chamber used to fire pottery, is an icon of the local Teochew and Chinese heritage. Explore one of two and the oldest dragon kiln in Singapore, located right next to NTU, Singapore's National Technological University. Visit for free to purchase antique furniture and housewares - great for families who want to explore the "jungle" side of Singapore!

Thow Kwang also offers pottery workshops for families who want to get hands-on: choose to attend either the full experience (Potter's Wheel + Handbuilding) or just Handbuilding! Be ready to get your hands dirty for a memorable experience. Dates are limited so check the link below to find out when public classes are open.

Location: Lorong Tawas 
Price: $35 and $60 for handbuilding only and full experience respectively 
Duration: 2-2.5 hours

Click here to find out more!
results.description: Get hands-on in pottery making and create your own colorful art piece!
results.name: Visit Singapore's Oldest Dragon Kiln and make your own unique pottery piece!

reviews.text: Decent dim sum. A lot of the nicer food were mixed with truffle. Service here was a bit slow as they seem short staffed for a hotel Chinese restaurant. It is expensive to eat here so would expect better service. There are some discounts available such as for amex love dining but other than that at full price it's not really worth

A restaurant that has good Lou Hei - not so sweet. The roasted chicken was nice and tender. The other dishes are so so. The attention of the service staff is not too bad. Generally a good place to go since it’s not as crowded as other restaurant.
Nice environment, very good and delicious Dim Sum.  They also served Peking Duck.
Had to book 2 days in advance, extremely slow service, nothing fantastic about the food, not worth the time and price. Definitely not returning.

The menu has changed and dim sum is no longer a standalone menu but rather has been incorporated into the main menu. There are now only about 10 items in the dim sum menu and prices have increased tremendously as well. 

The food still taste good but given the price increase, it does certainly leave a bit of a bitter taste to many customers. Having said that if you have AMEX Platinum Card or better, you can get great discounts of up to 50% off (excluding GST and service charge)

results.body:
Wan Hao Chinese Restaurant offers some of the best Chinese cuisines in Singapore, serving a tantalising collection of dishes that are suitable for family gathering and large groups. From Sweet and Sour Iberico Pork to Live Crab its extensive menu is reflective of the restaurant’s efforts to cater to every palate.

This restaurant is located in Singapore Marriott Tang Plaza Hotel along Orchard Road. Savour the culinary masterpieces of renowned Chinese Executive Chef Lau that have garnered a faithful following since 1995. Slightly crisp and flavourful, the famous Peking Duck is matched perfectly when served with authentic Chinese crepe. Wan Hao is also known for serving up good authentic dim sum.

MUST TRY: Indulge in their mouth-watering dishes such as Deep-Fried Prawn, Salted Egg Yolk Sauce, Steamed Shrimp Dumpling, Baked Egg Tart, Chilled Duck Wing, Spicy Passion Fruit Sauce, Roast Pork Belly, Hot and Sour Soup, Assorted Seafood, Shredded Beancurd.

For their drinks, they offer flower tea, and premium Chinese tea.
results.description: Wan Hao Chinese Restaurant offers some of the best Chinese cuisines in Singapore, serving a tantalising collection of dishes that are suitable for family gathering and large groups. From Sweet and Sour Iberico Pork to Live Crab its extensive menu is reflective of the restaurant’s efforts to cater to every palate. This restaurant is located in Singapore Marriott Tang Plaza Hotel along Orchard Road. Savour the culinary masterpieces of renowned Chinese Executive Chef Lau that have garnered a faithful following since 1995. Slightly crisp and flavourful, the famous Peking Duck is matched perfectly when served with authentic Chinese crepe. Wan Hao is also known for serving up good authentic dim sum. MUST TRY: Indulge in their mouth-watering dishes such as Deep-Fried Prawn, Salted Egg Yolk Sauce, Steamed Shrimp Dumpling, Baked Egg Tart, Chilled Duck Wing, Spicy Passion Fruit Sauce, Roast Pork Belly, Hot and Sour Soup, Assorted Seafood, Shredded Beancurd. For their drinks, they offer flower tea, and premium Chinese tea.
results.name: Wan Hao Chinese Restaurant

results.body:
Located on the fourth floor of Marina Square shopping mall, iSteamboat is an authentic Chinese restaurant that serves charmingly simple and pocket-friendly cuisine.

Introducing the FIRST Pagoda Steamboat buffet in Singapore since 2016! Savour in our mouthwatering buffet spreads and great selection of meats and seafood to grill. And did we mention cheese and salted egg dipping sauce! And there's more with steaming option for your seafood and even buns! Yes that is 4 tier for all to enjoy, bringing everyone a totally new and unique Steamboat experience.

Special selection of our in-house soup bases like Imperial Pork, Herbal Chicken and Tom Yum that guaranteed to delight your tastebuds. And there's more, with add-ons ala-carte menu like our favourite Salted Egg Sotong, Honey Sauce chicken, Cereal Prawns and many more. So wait no more and join us for a wonderful Steamboat experience, the PAGODA STYLE.

MUST TRIES: If it's a steamboat buffet that you desire, choose from Beef Slices, Fish Slices, Crabmeat Claws, Fish Dumplings and Golden Mushrooms.

If you'd rather homecooked ala carte alternatives, the menu includes: Black Pepper Pork, Dried Chilli Pork, Oyster Sauce Pork, Sambal Chicken, Black Pepper Chicken, Crispy Rojak Chicken, Assam Fish, Black Pepper Fish, Crispy Fillet Fish, Oyster Sauce Beansprouts, Sambal Beansprouts, Sambal Kangkong, Crispy Bacon Prawn, Assam Prawn and Grilled Prawn.
results.description: Located on the fourth floor of Marina Square shopping mall, iSteamboat is an authentic Chinese restaurant that serves charmingly simple and pocket-friendly cuisine. Introducing the FIRST Pagoda Steamboat buffet in Singapore since 2016! Savour in our mouthwatering buffet spreads and great selection of meats and seafood to grill. And did we mention cheese and salted egg dipping sauce! And there's more with steaming option for your seafood and even buns! Yes that is 4 tier for all to enjoy, bringing everyone a totally new and unique Steamboat experience. Special selection of our in-house soup bases like Imperial Pork, Herbal Chicken and Tom Yum that guaranteed to delight your tastebuds. And there's more, with add-ons ala-carte menu like our favourite Salted Egg Sotong, Honey Sauce chicken, Cereal Prawns and many more. So wait no more and join us for a wonderful Steamboat experience, the PAGODA STYLE. MUST TRIES: If it's a steamboat buffet that you desire, choose from Beef Slices, Fish Slices, Crabmeat Claws, Fish Dumplings and Golden Mushrooms. If you'd rather homecooked ala carte alternatives, the menu includes: Black Pepper Pork, Dried Chilli Pork, Oyster Sauce Pork, Sambal Chicken, Black Pepper Chicken, Crispy Rojak Chicken, Assam Fish, Black Pepper Fish, Crispy Fillet Fish, Oyster Sauce Beansprouts, Sambal Beansprouts, Sambal Kangkong, Crispy Bacon Prawn, Assam Prawn and Grilled Prawn.

reviews.text: Come here about once a week to get my mala fix. I've tried a bunch of their items including the hot pot, the fish, etc but my go to is easily the stir fry. You can select your preference for oil level and spicyness (but let's be honest you know why you're here). Staff doesn't speak great English but they're wonderful.

Good mala hotpot option.
Free flow condiments. - always a plus

results.body:
MOMO restaurants focus on providing good and healthy food with low price. We concentrate on selecting fresh ingredients, adopting healthy cooking style, maintaining food balance and avoiding food additives. Our restaurants serve high-quality dishes but not in high price. At MOMO, you can enjoy the restaurant environment at a food-court price.

Our most popular dishes are MOMO hot-pot, MOMO grilled fish, MOMO chilli pot. Momo classic Hot-Pot set which contains a selection of meat or seafood, a pot of soup basic, staple food and vegetable box which has many kinds of ingredients.

reviews.text:
Informal place, good for groups and for sharing, there are two big tables with lazy susans. Don't expect high standards of service, but the food is quite enjoyable.
We had pork noodles (the best! So savory and well balanced), fried dumplings, spicy potatoes and garlic spinach. Not a lot of variety of drinks, just ensure you ask if it is canned or fresh (for example for barley, lime tea). Do not accept amex but accept Visa. I already went back.
They offer a fairly authentic version  of northeastern Chinese cuisine. Nothing fancy but very comfort food for those in the know. Prices are very decent and consistency great.
Haven’t been here for more than 10 years. They still maintaining their nice yummy noodles and dumplings. Not pricy at all. Feeling like home cooking comfort food.
We enjoyed the food. Different from typical Singaporean food. Spicy, nicely cooked in a clean but simple environment.  Reasonably priced,  promptly served, pleasant, unobtrusive staff
Many different north east Chinese dishes to select. Price is reasonable n shop keeper is polite.  Good place for lunch n dinner

results.body: Run by a family from China, this restaurant serves Northern Chinese cuisine, such as xiao long bao (dumplings), Szechuan spicy soup and la mian.
results.description: Run by a family from China, this restaurant serves Northern Chinese cuisine, such as xiao long bao (dumplings), Szechuan spicy soup and la mian.
results.name: Tall Girl Chinese Restaurant

reviews.text: Woah... the lobster porridge is fantastic!! They'll charge you by the number of lobsters ordered... not cheap!! Other dishes were really good too... a great place to celebrate a parent's birthday or a colleague's promotion... :)

Rating given for order taking.
Our 1st time and staff ask us to refer to menu when we ask for recommendation.
There were 6 of us and he simply ask how many lobster we want for the lobster porridge without elaborating further, ie is lobster big or small ones, or how many lobster is required to make a pot of porridge for 6 tasty.
Nice place, good food on a rainy afternoon :)

One of the famous Chinese restaurant located in Little India area. As we went there early evening, it was not crowded. But when we finished our dinner, got crowded. Road is filled with parked car, but on the other side of road you can find car park on the TOP of old shopping complex.
Extremely small portion. We literally had 1 cube of tofu and 2 tiny slices of "kurobuta" each. Its like chinese fine dining :(

results.body:
Wan He Lou is located in a shophouse on Maude Road, at the heart of the Jalan Besar neighbourhood. The Chinese restaurant is helmed by Chef Lau Siaw Dee, who previously won an award at an international culinary event coinciding with the Beijing Olympics. The restaurant is brightly lit, with sufficient breathing space between the simple wood furnishings.

MUST TRIES: The restaurant is best known for its Teochew style Lobster Porridge(S$31.90, half a lobster), which consists of loose rice grains cooked in a simmering golden broth, enriched with lobster roe and served with a meaty lobster half. The Crispy Lotus Root with Salted Egg also makes for a good snack before the meal.

The Crispy Lotus Root with Salted Egg also makes for a good snack before the meal.

reviews.text:
All the dish are nice!
Especially hot and spicy deep fried chicken wing is so delicious. It's spicy with sichuan pepper so my tongue get numb. So addictive!
Non sense.Abusive.

results.body:
Ju Hui Ge Northeastern Chinese Cuisine 聚匯閣 's theme is organic and nostalgic, even the wine container is the old-fashioned so-called ChaGangZi. There is also a ‘memory wall’ in their restaurant so that you can take photos with friends and relive previous moments.

 

They serve mainly cuisines from Sichuan and Northeast China. Signature ones are Large Pot Steward, Braised Fish Head with Tofu, and Heavily Sauced Bone. The chef has more than 20 years experience in cooking. They also offer home-made pork dumplings with various vegetable now, promising an authentic taste of dumplings from Northeast China.

 

In addition, Ju Hui Ge is also able to hold small parties, like birthday party and company gathering. Free delivery service is also available, but only limited to Geylang area.

reviews.text: Good service and the food is delicious. Must try the kurobuta pork and shark bone fish maw soup! Will definitely come back again!
Fantastic lobster meesua, lot of good drinks selection and service was excellent 😍😍
V deep wok high fire dishes smell permeates within the restaurant
Fine dining with very good chefs in the kitchen! They have created us a tasting mneu, which was so yummy!!!
Fried rice feels like is loaded with msg. Abalone sashmi seems gimmicky, all we taste is the pepper. Overall very disappointed with the food. Service is so so.

results.body: Formerly known as Chinois, this Chinese fine dining restaurant at Hotel Michael™ sees celebrity chef Susur Lee’s signature contemporary Chinese dishes sharing the spotlight with senior executive chef Ken Ling’s fiery Hunanese and Teochew delights. The signature Roast London Duck, with its crispy aromatic skin and succulent duck meat, is a must-order. Visitors should also try the restaurant’s Singapore Slaw, chef Susur’s twist on the local yusheng salad that is traditionally eaten during Chinese New Year. Vegetarian menus are available in the restaurant, which also has three private rooms that can seat four to 12 for groups who prefer private dining.
results.description: This Chinese fine dining restaurant dishes out Chinese, Hunanese and Teochew delights.

address.buildingName: Resorts World™ Sentosa, Hotel Michael Lobby

results.name: Tunglok Heen

reviews.text: One of the best Chinese restaurant in Singapore that excellent food. The service staff provide top notch service. Place is specious and good for family gathering. Must try dish includes the roast chicken, steam prawns, fried rice, crab meat stew and fish

The food served here are delicious especially their Roast pork which is just amazing the skin is very crispy and together with the sauce provided is just another world would highly recommend anyone who is intending to eat here or order this. Their service here are also superb especially their staff who will go the extra to serve the customer

Friendly service staff. Newly renovated. Food is good as usual. Their popiah is tasty. They are having a limited-time promo where you mention them on social media (check out for details), you get a free popiah! Enjoyed my meal there with family
Reserved 4 tables for family dinner. Given the top floor which comes with karaoke system. Food is nice.

Hosted my wedding lunch in this restaurant. Specially thank Joseph who coordinated the event surprisingly well despite not much prior discussion or rehearsal and provided additional decor for the reception. Every table was laid with red cloth which makes the entire venue having the chinese wedding feel. It helps that the venue has recently been renovated to make the seating more spacious and minimal view blockage to the stage. Many wedding guests praised on the food quality particularly the shark fin. Definitely recommend holding small wedding event (

results.body: Dating back to 1929, Spring Court Restaurant remains a family-run establishment and is one of the oldest restaurants in Singapore. It is known for its signature Peking duck and specialty dishes such as fried crab and chicken liver rolls with salted egg. For birthday celebrations, guests can order the mini longevity buns filled with lotus seed paste. The dish is presented with a calligraphy performance and birthday song sang by a member of staff. Festive sets and group dining deals are available. Main courses start from S$20.
results.description: This family-run establishment is the oldest Chinese restaurant in Singapore.
results.name: Spring Court Restaurant

results.description: Zhe Bian Lai serves Chinese cuisine. Come and try their dishes at Kallang Bahru.

reviews.text: We order lunch from here about once every 2 weeks and everyone loves it. The spiciness is just right and well the taste is as best it can get.
Excellent service. The spicy lamb is something to die for. Cooked just right with the right chewiness and spiciness.
Hot and spicy fish  and stir fry yellow beef. Wonderful, spicy but not the extreme.
Excellent food. Very reasonably priced.
Located about 4minutes away from Tg Pagar  mrt. The fish is fresh and tasty. Yang chow fried rice can be improved with more eggs added. Fried beef was ok. Staffs are very friendly.

results.body: Guo Se Tian Xiang serves Chinese and Hunan dishes in CBD.

reviews.text: Top notch feed. Super cheap, super good.
The street has probably over 100 restaurants. This one serves good rice noodles.
Great vegetarian options

앞에 작은 가게에 줄이 너무 길어서 우연히 들어갔는데 은근 맛집이었어요 ㅋㅋㅋ

results.body: Yu Zhi Zhi serves Chinese cuisine. They are known for their Signature Grilled Fish with Douhua.
results.description: Yu Zhi Zhi serves Chinese cuisine. They are known for their Signature Grilled Fish with Douhua.

reviews.text: Celebrations, birthdays, anniversaries. You can celebrate any party here. Rest assured their staff will be there to assist you if you don't know what to order. They will recommend the best in the menu. Their prices are reasonable for everything that they offer to customers

Such a fine place if you want to have a taste of China in Singapore. Ate here on my first and second day of my trip. Even when you have no idea what to eat, just look at the photos and ask the very kind waiters for the special dish that they have. You will have a full delicious meal here I tellyou!

A decent restaurant if you want really delicious meals. Their menu overflows with specialty dishes. I particularly like their seafood hotplate. When it was served in our table,the smell was already very tempting!Big serving too. :)

Definitely must try! Thanks to our boss from bringing us here. The lady who assisted us in picking food and serving the dishes was always smiling and happy to assist us. The service time was fast too.
The best place for special celebrations! We just had our family dinner here and we had a terrific wonderful dining experience. Try their Hot and Spicy Boiling Fish Fillet. Really commendable!

results.body: Hutong means back alley in Chinese. Hutong offers traditional Northern Chinese cuisine and its décor comprise elements of traditional Chinese culture. Designed to exude the charm of old China, antique dark-wooded screens and tables are accompanied by billowing Chinese silk drapes and red lanterns, creating a sentimental vibe of reminiscence of the beauty of ancient Beijing. Despite its traditional décor, Hutong offers a contemporary twist on traditional Northern Chinese cuisines.

reviews.text: We absolutely loved dining at Ibid. The ambience is chic yet informal. The food is delicious and creative, whilst paying homage to regional Chinese ingredients. The hospitality is stellar. I was celebrating a special occasion which turned out to be even more special, as we were treated by Ibid as a surprise! We also got superb recommendations on where to continue the night! Thank you Ibid!!

Great little spot for an intimate dinner for couples or small groups. The menu is unique, and you can tell the people working at Ibid really have a passion for creating unique food.  A gem of a restaurant.

The menu was thoughtfully conceived - every course was of a different cooking method. Some really creative use of local ingredients and mixture of flavors and textures. Overall a lovely dining experience and will definitely be back for more!
Nice atmosphere, knowledgeable staff, super tasting menu and a chef happy to talk about his inspirations and creations. Excellent meal. Well done chef and team

Was introduced to this restaurant through some friends and it was really quite a lovely experience dining in the place. Every single dish was a gastronomic delight, and the entire meal was well worth its price. Looking forward to trying out their new menu during my next visit!

results.body: Founded by chef Woo Wai Leong, winner of MasterChef Asia 2015, Restaurant Ibid pays homage to chef Woo’s Chinese heritage as well as the Western culinary skills he has acquired over the years. A favourite from the restaurant’s menu is the Escargot Skewers, charcoal grilled escargot brushed with a chilli bean sauce and wrapped in betel leaf. The Beef Short Rib is cooked sous vide for 48 hours before being served alongside Chinese pear and black fungus. From the dinner menu, diners can choose from a four course (S$78++), six-course (S$88++) or eight-course (S$118++) meal.
results.description: Savour Chinese dishes that incorporate Western culinary techniques by Woo Wai Leong, winner of MasterChef Asia 2015.
results.name: Restaurant Ibid

reviews.text: This is a place to go if you have friends from outside of Singapore come to visit.  Many local cuisines can be found here.  Not the best but definitely above average.  The price is acceptable. Services are quite good.

Food is top notch and so is the service.  Wonderful breakfast spread ranging from local to western. There's also a section with a small selection of gluten free bakes. Overall a lovely way to start your day.

Food items are really good, and there is a very big variety of cuisines, including Indian, Chinese, Indonesian and others. The price is pretty high per person, and unless you can really eat a lot (its a buffet style), the steep price doesn't really justify the amount of food one can eat. Still a good experience nonetheless.
Drink is absolutely good. The fare is competitive. The place is nice too.

Excellent restaurant and buffet.  The wide range of local dishes makes it an ideal place to take visitors from overseas or for a party.  Eaten here a few times and never disappoints.  Only issue is that sometime wait time for table or drinks can be a while.

results.body: Visitors seeking authentic hawker fare in a more refined setting should head to StraitsKitchen at the Grand Hyatt® Singapore, where the chefs prepare food on the spot at the live stations. This restaurant serves a sumptuous buffet spread of local favourites (lunch: S$56++; dinner: S$68++), including dishes of the Peranakans (Straits-born people of Chinese and Malay/Indonesian heritage), Chinese and Indian cuisine, and popular hawker staples such as satay (grilled meat skewers), laksa (spicy coconut milk-based noodle soup) and chicken rice, all in a chic steel-and-marble dining hall. For dessert, the freshly made nonya kueh (bite-sized snacks or desserts) and homemade ice creams are not to be missed at StraitsKitchen. Child rates available.
results.description: Enjoy a sumptuous buffet spread of local delights ranging from Peranakan to Chinese to Indian dishes at this chic restaurant.
results.name: StraitsKitchen

reviews.text: It is one of the best choices in Singapore if you love dumplings and authentic Northeast Chinese food. They serve tasty dumplings with different tastes with reasonable price. Their hot dishes are yummy as well. But what has impressed me is the environment- compared to other Chinese restaurants it is a clean and decent place! Please keep the good work to let more people know Chinese food :))

Was looking for a good dumpling place but it turns out that their other hot dishes and skewers are equally brilliant. Their homemade toufu and mackerel dumplings are hidden gems. The environment is comfortable and clean, the guys at the shop are helpful and friendly.

This place is really good, their bitter melon salad is unique and delicious, healthy but most importantly tasty. You can order the usual northeastern Chinese fare but they just make everything better, not overly salty, not overly greasy (as long as you don't order Sichuan inspired dishes) and very generous portions. First ate here 2 weeks ago and I've gone back 4 times since, if you think all Chinese food is stirfried and greasy, go to this place and order from the appetizer/cold dish menu. Oh and they make dumplings too. Yes they accept credit card.
Love the food here!! Especially 辣子鸡

Was walking along Chinatown found this gem! North Eastern Chinese Restaurant! New establishment. 
It was tastefully delicious Chongqing chinese home cook meal! Got very friendly waitresses, food was good. Definitely will bring friends and try!

reviews.text: Like this hot pot place. Price increased a lot comparing to years ago. But food quality is guaranteed. Will definitely come back.
Good place to visit if you like mutton, flavour is a bit on the strong side

Great place for mutton lover
The booth for steamboat is nice
The steamboat set is worth the price, it comes with mutton prime rib, slice mutton, mince mutton dumping, goat's kidney and stomach, a basket of mix mushroom and vegetable.
The BBQ羊肉串 is great also
But 手撕饼 is disappointed
Great food and great service. They gave us a couple of free dishes when they know that it was my friend's birthday

Bad service from the male staff. We have booked the table for 2, when we arrive we saw the further inside 4 seaters was available but the male staff told us that’s for 4 persons, so we have to seat at the table next to entrance which is quite hot. Later another 2 customers arrive and they seat at the earlier 4 seaters that we have requested :S
We ordered ‘Chong Qing Xian mian’ which is ‘mala’ spicy based noodle, staff brought us the wrong order which was lamb soup based noodle(non-spicy) and was returned back. Subsequently our spicy noodle was served but it’s obvious that they just add more chili into the wrongly ordered noodle which is not ‘mala’ at all. 
Disappointed!

reviews.text: Quality Mutton and the soup is very flavourful. Interesting side dishes too. Relatively the quality of food is good and the price paid is worthy of its food standard. Highly recommended. The staff service standards are impressive too.

Visited this place several times when I crave for mutton ribs. Their mutton hot pot is uniquely delicious. I specially favour the mutton ribs so I will exchange some other material for that if I am having hot pot package. They also offer set meal during lunch like what the photo shows.
Really like this place - great mutton soup steamboat and great service. Recommend trying the cucumber appetizer and must order the wan ton. Great place for a social gathering!
Very good food but not too cheap. Love their mutton soup. Flavorful side dishes.
If you are craving for mutton/lamp. This is the place to go.  They claim that the meat is imported from New Zealand. Love the taste of the lamp rack. All other dish are as good and value for money.

results.body: Chuan Yang Ji Mutton Soup Steamboat serves Chinese cuisine and steamboat. They specializes in mutton ribs and soup.
results.description: Chuan Yang Ji Mutton Soup Steamboat serves Chinese cuisine and steamboat. They specializes in mutton ribs and soup.

results.body:
Hidden among skyscrapers, cosy Mikkeller Bar Singapore is housed on the 2nd floor of a conserved heritage shop-house along Purvis Street. This was once the settlement grounds for the ethnic Chinese communities.  Search for the shop with the striking red façade, walk up the red carpet and you shall find your paradise. Come thirsty and hungry for you will be rewarded with 25 taps of Mikkeller’s best beers & other fine suds, a big bottle selection and a food menu designed to pair with beers. Don’t leave without a gift too – grab your favourite Mikkeller caps, shirts, bags and glassware.

Find us easily. Several landmarks surround us – including Raffles Hotel (2 mins walk), Intercontinental Hotel (3 mins walk), Bugis MRT station (5 mins walk) & City Hall MRT station (7 mins walk).

reviews.text:
This bar, together with Druggists, are the best craft beer bars in Singapore.

Very good and diverse selection of beers - most of them are Mikkeller, but there are enough from other breweries too. You can try some quite interesting local beers too.

The staff are knowledgeable and polite and they know what they are selling. They can give you good advice if you tell them your taste.

The atmosphere is excellent. It's very clean and there is plenty of natural light. I wish they didn't try to turn up the music volume though. Otherwise, the music selection is good.

Again, like in Druggists, I wish they offered some nuts like salty peanuts or salty almonds. This would go perfect with these beers. Most people who love craft beer and go there because of the beer, they just need to have some simple salty nuts, not those "fancy" fried food. Nuts are simple and they wouldn't even need a cook or kitchen for that.

The lack of nuts is the only downside though, otherwise I highly recommend this bar to anyone who loves beer.

This is a good place for craft beers. We have been looking for a good bar for a long time today. This was a little slice of heaven for us. Beer is a bit pricey but they're really good. Wide selection of beers also.

Small & cozy. Lots of bottled or tap beers to choose from - all very tasty. Ask the staff for recommendations. 

They didn't have any food other than chips, but you can get your own food up here and eat. 

Bonus - They play nice indie music all day!
Superb craft beers - and if you come between 4 to 8pm (which is also aptly named as slacker hour), you also get away with some of them for only $9 a pint!
Friendky staff, good selection of beers, nice interior

results.description: Hidden among skyscrapers, cosy Mikkeller Bar is housed on the 2nd floor of a heritage shop-house. 25 taps- craft beers, wine, mead, cocktails & food.
results.name: MIKKELLER BAR SINGAPORE

results.body: The Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall is dedicated to Dr Sun Yat Sen, who headed the 1911 Chinese Revolution that eventually led to the downfall of the Qing Dynasty. Not many know that Singapore served as a hub for his revolutionary activities in Southeast Asia. The two-storey colonial-style villa that currently houses the museum was once the regional headquarters of the Chinese Revolutionary Alliance. The museum expands on the connections between Dr Sun and Singapore in five galleries with artefacts, artworks and multimedia exhibits. Free guided tours in English and Mandarin are available on selected days on a first-come, first-served basis. There is a 20% discount for purchases of 20 or more adult tickets. A discounted family package of five tickets is also available.

reviews.text: Learnt quite a bit of history in there, particularly how amongst the overseas Chinese there was a strong sense of nationalism and identification with the motherland. Today are such sentiments still as strong with first generation migrants? If so, how much of that identity is transmitted to the next generation? Having been there, I think this monument is an important marker of our evolving identity.

A small, humble and comprehensive museum dedicated to the time Sun Yat Sen was in Singapore including stories of his local comrades. There was a free tour provided by volunteers that we took which was informative!

Heritage architecture and air-con...what more could you ask for? This boutique museum is just gorgeous and gives you a fascinating insight into Singapore's history around the turn of the century with a focus on Dr. Sun Yat Sen. Located nearby to a small modern shopping center and many nice restaurants for lunch including Pistachio Middle Eastern & Mediterranean Grill.
Well-maintained building and exhibits. It's covered under the Balestier Heritage Trail so you can read about it before deciding if it's worth your time to visit
Closer to my place, wasnt much explored.. decent place to take kids on a weekend

pricing.others: Free admission for Singaporeans, Permanent Residents & Children under the age of six; Foreigners S$6; Foreign Students, Senior Citizens & Children from age six to 12 S$4

results.description: The museum expands on the connections between Dr Sun Yat Sen, who headed the 1911 Chinese Revolution, and Singapore with artefacts, artworks and multimedia exhibits.
results.name: Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall

results.body: National Gallery Singapore, in the heart of the Civic District is a state-of-the-art facility with an impressive collection of local & Southeast Asian artists. Two national monuments - the City Hall and former Supreme Court - were remodelled to create this stunning gallery. It is the biggest visual arts venue in Singapore housing the world's largest public collection of modern Southeast Asian art from the 19th century to the present. Its esteemed Southeast Asian catalogue carries names such as Indonesian Romantic painter Raden Saleh and Fernando Amorsolo from the Philippines.

reviews.text: A nice place to spend approximately half a day. Very beautiful exhibits and the building is huge. It's easy to miss out on some beautiful art if you can't figure out the navigation inside. I went on a Saturday when the entry happened to be free and it wasn't very crowded. You can enjoy the exhibits and pop into one of their many restaurants. I was surprised to find good food for a pretty decent amount in one of the cafes.

Husband works next to this place at the Supreme Courts so this place is my coffee fix or waiting area till he is off work. Sit around, or walk the galleries. Very very relaxing and good fun. It used to be the old Supreme Courts and wow, they have really preserved this place really well. Well done.

results.body:
Founded in 2003, The Intan is a Peranakan heritage home-museum. The brainchild of antique collector and owner Alvin Yapp, The Intan (meaning 'rose-cut diamond' in Malay) enlightens its guests about the multi-facetted aspects of Peranakan culture through a kaleidoscope of rare historical artefacts, intriguing personal stories, and authentic dining experiences.
Located in the heart of Joo Chiat, a traditional Peranakan enclave and Singapore’s ﬁrst heritage town (2011), The Intan offers personalised tours conducted by Alvin, which culminate with authentic Peranakan tea sessions and dinners inspired by his mother. The Intan also doubles up as a unique event space, having hosted a variety of activities that included jewellery exhibitions, art shows and violin recitals.
Awarded Best Tour Experience by Singapore Tourism Awards 2016 and voted Best Overall Experience in Singapore’s inaugural Museum Roundtable Awards, The Intan has been featured internationally on CNN Travel, Discovery Channel and National Geographic. Singapore Travelholic lists The Intan as the top 5 Peranakan activities to do in Singapore.
With a vision to promote Peranakan culture beyond Singapore, The Intan’s collection has been showcased in places such as Croatia, Hawaii and Hong Kong

reviews.text: A great stop; well worth leaving the more congested tourist  parts of the city. Learn not just about Peranakan Culture, but gain a better understanding of Singapore and the relationship between it's different groups. Highly recommended.
Nice place

A lovely museum, and the multi-hyphenated museum curator, Peranakan owner bring this place alive. The haven of collectables is alive with his explanation into the history, culture and lifestyle of the Peranakan. Highly recommended for those who are keen to know more about Alvin, his story and traditions of the Peranakan.

This is a place not to miss, if you are keen to appreciate the Peranakan Culture. For the first time, i got a glimpse into their living days, on what makes them significant. Walking into the intan, is a walk back in time, hosted by the Peranakans themselves. Great stuff!
Good

results.body: The origins of Methodism in Singapore can be traced back to the arrival of Reverend William F. Oldham in 1885, who was the nation’s first resident Methodist missionary. Services were held at the Town Hall (today’s Victoria Memorial Hall) until the first chapel opened a year later. In recognition of the church’s contribution to mission work and education, Singapore’s then-governor Sir John Anderson granted it a piece of land in 1907. This is the exact piece of land at Fort Canning (today’s site) of Wesley Methodist Church. It was styled after English Gothic buildings, featuring exposed brickwork. First known as Methodist Episcopal Church, it was renamed after John Wesley, the founder of Methodism, in 1910. Membership has soared since then, and the church has undergone several renovations to extend its premises. Opening Hours: Mon-Sun, 9am-6pm; Closed on Public Holidays, the day after Easter Sunday and the day after Christmas Day.

results.body: Dedicated to goddess Sri Veeramakaliamman, the temple was once known as “Soonambu Kambam Kovil” or “temple at the lime village” in Tamil. At that time, most of its faithful worked at lime kilns in the vicinity. During World War II, many people hid here when Japanese air raids took place.  Remarkably, the temple and all its statues were unaffected by the bombings. Its latest renovation, completed in 2014, included the addition of a six-storey building with staff quarters, a multipurpose hall and a wedding hall.

reviews.text: Sri Veeramakaliamman Temple is little India's busiest and oldest temple. The temple was built in 1881 and was renovated in 1999 and again in 2014. The temple is dedicated to the Hindu goddess Kali which is popular in Bengal, the birthplace of the laborers who built the temple. You can enter the temple and enjoy its colorful statues and the beautiful detail of the architecture. It is free to visit and be sure to take your shoes off before entering the temple.
Fascinating and beautifully made. Details in sculptures were awesome!! You get very good vibes here. Must visit if you're in little india
Very peaceful and blessed place to be. Very majestic sculptures. The positive vibration in the temple are very strong.
It is a very holy place. It has many fascinating sculptures. The goddess here is considered very powerful. It also attracts many foreigners as they come here to learn about the Indian Culture.

This Temple is one of the earliest Hindu Temples in Singapore, It is a famous and the oldest Hindu Temple in the area.It was built by pioneer Indian migrants during the early British Colonial Days.It provides religious and cultural needs for the Hindu population since then till today.On special religious occassions, the temple is crowded with devotees.It is also an icon and a tourist attraction in the Little India area.The temple has undergone renovations and looks much nicer and brighter now

results.body: Visitors looking to photograph a historical Singapore icon should head to the Singapore River, where a white statue of Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles - the founder of modern Singapore - stands guard. It is on this historic site where the British official first set foot on the island in 1819. A dark bronze statue of Sir Stamford Raffles is also located just a short walk away at the Victoria Theatre and Victoria Concert Hall.

reviews.text: This is definitely one of those cities that is best enjoyed at night when the buildings come to life and show you incredible views everywhere you look. This picture was taken close to the statue of Sir Stamford Raffles by the canal, on a walk from Clarke's Quay to Sand's. Something I can recommend to everyone visiting the city!

Should be Sang Nila Utama found the kingdom of Singapore, and the first foreigner to discover was the Yuan dynasty's Wang Dayuan who built diplomatic relations with the kingdom, so not Stamford Raffles.

results.body:
Situated in the heart of the Singapore Civic District, National Gallery Singapore oversees the largest public collection of modern art in Southeast Asia. Housed in two beautifully restored national monuments - City Hall and former Supreme Court - are impeccably curated exhibitions that reveal the cultural legacy and art histories of Southeast Asia. 

Come visit the Gallery today and discover the rich art and cultural heritage of Singapore and Southeast Asia through stunning modern art masterpieces.

results.body: Set up in 2003, the Ngee Ann Cultural Centre comprises the Ngee Ann Kongsi Heritage Hall and Collections Gallery. The former commemorates the entrepreneurial spirit of pioneers from the Ngee Ann Kongsi, a Teochew charitable welfare organisation founded in 1845. Its displays of archives and artefacts, such as account books from the 1920s, elaborate on the Kongsi’s history and its contributions to the development of Singapore.

results.body: The Sultan Mosque, built in 1824, is a landmark of the Kampong Glam district which attracts many who are keen to discover the culture & history of Malays. Also known as Masjid Sultan, the mosque’s name pays homage to Sultan Hussein Mohamed Shah, the first Sultan of Singapore and 18th ruler of Johor. In 1975, it was gazetted as a national monument. The mosque’s mass prayer hall can host up to 5,000 visitors. While its 2 giant golden domes make for an impressive sight, their bases are adorned with glass bottle ends, which were donated by Muslims during its construction.

reviews.text: The most lovely place I found in Singapore was the Masjid Sultan. The overall exterior & interior is mind blowing. The streets nearby the Masjid is very lovely to walk through. It will make you feel different. Lots of souvenir & food shops are just nearby the Masjid.

A beautiful mosque with a history. A famous tourist attraction too. There r visiting times for tourist to look from inside the mosque. A certain dress code is required. But the mosque staff has extra clothes available for tourists so they got u covered there.

One of my favourite mosque in Singapore. It’s a must to visit here when you visit Singapore. Beautiful mosque. Nice design. And the best Part is this mosque located opposite the murtabak restaurant, Arab street.

Very comfortable for prayers. Their community very friendly. Even non muslim can come inside to learn more about Islamic religious. The interior design so beautiful

results.body: Maghain Aboth Synagogue - which translates to “Shield of our Fathers” - is established as Southeast Asia’s oldest surviving synagogue, and visits are by appointment only. The 2-storey Jewish house of worship is easily distinguished from its neighbours by the three blue Stars of David emblazoned on the cream-coloured façade, along with its name in Hebrew. Unlike other places of worship, the prayer hall does not bear any images of gods or prophets, as this is forbidden in Judaism. A tour of the interior reveals a mix of neoclassical and colonial architecture.

results.body: Founded in 1921 by the Venerable Sik Zhuan Dao from China, the Buddhist monastery originally built amidst a rubber plantation is Singapore’s largest, at 75,470sqm or the equivalent of 10.7 football fields. In Mandarin, ‘Kong Meng San’ means ‘Bright Hill’, representative of Guanyin Bodhisattva’s Pureland. Apart from being a place of worship, it has traditionally served as lodging for visiting monks. The compound has multiple halls, a bell tower and the Pagoda of 10,000 Buddhas—capped with a bell-shaped stupa. While the stupa’s exterior is decorated with gold-coloured mosaic tiles, its interior features over 10,000 Buddha statuettes. Visitors can end their visit by reflecting under a Bodhi tree (the tree is supposedly a descendant of the sacred Bodhi tree at Bodh Gaya). Non-vegetarian food and pets are not allowed inside the temple.

reviews.text: This is an amazing Buddhist Temple! Actually a cluster of buildings / temples that are all beautiful with ornate carvings, restful ponds, amazing statues and of course magnificent places of worship. Be sure to bring a camera as the beauty is incredible!

The largest monastery in Singapore. This place could require at least 45mins to 1 hours if you want to walk through the whole complex in details! The architecture of the complex is amazing, information board is easy to understand too! Highly recommend to visit if you haven’t been here before.
Yearly place to visit during Qing Ming. The crowd is usually crazy in those couple of weeks but the monastery simple improved on the crowd, smoke management annually.
Nice Buddhist temple set in tranquil surroundings. They offer ash storage and ancestral tablets. Beautiful resting place for jyour beloved ones. Highly recommend visiting the splendid temple grounds

Iconic Buddhist temple that occupies very large grounds. Definitely one of the biggest temple in Singapore and happens to be the largest Buddhist temple on Singapore. 

It is also a columbarium, so expect this place to be extremely crowded during certain festivals, such as Chinese New Year and Qin Ming.
